resources.string: Changing the URL, username or password will erase all the data. Are you sure?
Given name cannot contain symbols or numbers
Middle name cannot contain symbols or numbers
Family name cannot contain symbols or numbers
Fill at least one address field
Offline mode is not supported during first login.Enable online mode and then try again.
You are now in offline mode.
Incorrect username or password entered. Please try again.
You have no internet connection.\nPlease check phone or Wi-Fi connection and signal strength and try again.
Are you sure you want to logout from OpenMRS client?
Your credentials have been changed in the web app. You are logged out automatically.
Are you sure you want to end this visit?
Are you sure you want to start visit for %1$s now?
There are already active visits of %1$s. Try synchronizing patient or closing previous visits
Are you sure you want to delete this patient?
All patient information entered will be erased
There are no concepts in DB!
Please press BACK again to exit
Failed to fetch patient from database

Patient photo cannot be synced due to server error: %1$s
No internet connection. Patient Registration data is saved locally
and will sync when internet connection is restored.
An error occurred. Invalid or corrupted form file.
To use faster and more accurate similar patient resolution, upgrade the Registration Core Module to 1.7 or higher
Invalid login or password, please try again.
Camera permission is needed to capture photo.
Camera permission was denied. Please consider granting it in order to access the camera
Camera permission was denied with never ask again
Patient not yet registered, cannot create encounter.
Sorry ! An Unknown error has occurred. Please report the details to developers so that it can be resolved as soon as possible.
All patient information entered will be lost.
Vitals can only be captured for patients currently in a visit.
Are you sure you want to delete these patients?
* Identifier can be anything. Eg. Doctor, Nurse, Clerk, etc
offline providers fetched couldn\'t sync with the database device offline
provider will be synced to the server when device gets connected to network
updated provider will be synced to the server when device gets connected to network
Provider will be removed from the server when you\'re back online
The global OpenMRS community works together to build the world\'s leading open source electronic medical record system.
Register new patients to our server.
You can find and monitor those patients.
We help you monitor patient visits too.
You can manage providers using our app.
You can change your location at a simple click.
Try out our dark mode feature.\nExciting? Let\'s get started.
Get started with our user guide
Error in Authenticate Check Service Response
Patient not yet registered. No internet connection. Form data is saved locally and will sync when internet connection is restored.
Sync is off. Turn on sync to save form data.
There is no encounter type called %1$s
You can select only one similar patient
Cannot start a patient visit manually in offline mode.

"Patient[ %1$i ] cannot be synced due to request error %2$s
Patient %1$s cannot be updated due to server error will retry sync %2$s
Sync is off. Patient Update data is saved locally and will sync when online mode is restored.
Syncing switched on, attempting to sync patients and form data
Our Team will try our best to help you. Please reach out to us by using the services above.
There are no email clients installed.

Unable to get the latest recorded allergies!
The patient\'s allergy will be removed from server. Are you sure you want to continue?

The patient\'s allergy will be added to server. Are you sure you want to continue?

There was an unexpected error while creating the allergy. Please try again!
OpenMRS is a global community of truly dedicated, talented, and generous contributors who build and maintain the OpenMRS platform and other, foundational OpenMRS technical products.
OpenMRS is a platform that countries and implementers use to create a customized EMR system in response to actual needs on the ground.
Diagnosis: Severe Pneumonia OR very Severe Disease
Give first dose of antibiotic-intramuscular injection, Ampicillin and Gentamicin. Oral Amoxicillin otherwise.

For AMPICILLIN: Dilute 500mg vial with 2.1 ml sterile water (500mg/2.5ml). Give 1ml ONE TIME via intramuscular injection. If referral is not possible or delayed, repeat the same dose of AMPICILLIN every 6 hours.

For AMPICILLIN: Dilute 500mg vial with 2.1 ml sterile water (500mg/2.5ml). Give 2ml ONE TIME via intramuscular injection. If referral is not possible or delayed, repeat the same dose of AMPICILLIN every 6 hours.

For AMPICILLIN: Dilute 500mg vial with 2.1 ml sterile water (500mg/2.5ml). Give 3ml ONE TIME via intramuscular injection. If referral is not possible or delayed, repeat the same dose of AMPICILLIN every 6 hours.

For AMPICILLIN: Dilute 500mg vial with 2.1 ml sterile water (500mg/2.5ml). Give 5ml ONE TIME via intramuscular injection. If referral is not possible or delayed, repeat the same dose of AMPICILLIN every 6 hours.
For GENTAMICIN: (2ml/40mg/ml vial). Give 0.5–1 ml ONE TIME via intramuscular injection. If referral is not possible or delayed, repeat gentamicin once daily.
For GENTAMICIN: (2ml/40mg/ml vial). Give 1.1–1.8 ml ONE TIME via intramuscular injection. If referral is not possible or delayed, repeat gentamicin once daily.
For GENTAMICIN: (2ml/40mg/ml vial). Give 1.9–2.7 ml ONE TIME via intramuscular injection. If referral is not possible or delayed, repeat gentamicin once daily.
For GENTAMICIN: (2ml/40mg/ml vial). Give 2.8–3.5 ml ONE TIME via intramuscular injection. If referral is not possible or delayed, repeat gentamicin once daily.
For DIAZEPAM: (10mg/2ml). Give 0.5 ml DIAZEPAM injection solution per rectum using a small syringe without a needle (like a tuberculin syringe) or using a catheter.
For DIAZEPAM: (10mg/2ml). Give 1.0 ml DIAZEPAM injection solution per rectum using a small syringe without a needle (like a tuberculin syringe) or using a catheter.
For DIAZEPAM: (10mg/2ml). Give 1.5 ml DIAZEPAM injection solution per rectum using a small syringe without a needle (like a tuberculin syringe) or using a catheter.
For DIAZEPAM: (10mg/2ml). Give 2.0 ml DIAZEPAM injection solution per rectum using a small syringe without a needle (like a tuberculin syringe) or using a catheter.
Turn the child to his/her side and clear the airway. Avoid putting things in the mouth.
Give DIAZEPAM injection solution per rectum using a small syringe without a needle (like a tuberculin syringe) or using a catheter.
Check for low blood sugar, then treat or prevent.
Give oxygen if available and REFER URGENTLY
If convulsions have not stopped after 10 minutes repeat diazepam dose
If wheezing now, give salbutamol 4–6 puffs with spacer or 1 nebulization (2.5–5mg) if available while awaiting referral. Do not delay referral.
If oxygen level is greater than 90%, start oxygen therapy if available while awaiting referral. Do not delay referral.
Treat to prevent low blood sugar
Ask the mother to breastfeed the child
If the child is unable to breastfeed, give 50ml expressed breast milk, a breast-milk substitute, or sugar water (4 teaspoons sugar [20g] in 200ml clean water)
If unable to swallow, give 50ml milk or sugar water by nasogastric tube OR 1 teaspoon sugar moistened with 1–2 drops of water sublingually, repeating every 20 minutes while awaiting referral
Diagnosis: No signs of Pneumonia or Wheezing illness
You have selected that this child does NOT have a cough or difficulty breathing
ALRITE is to help diagnose children with a cough or difficulty breathing
No antibiotics or a bronchodilator needed for breathing difficulty
Give inhaled salbutamol , 2–4 puffs every 4–6 hours for 5 days

A spacer is a way of delivering the bronchodilator drugs effectively into the lungs. No child under 5 years should be given an inhaler without a spacer. A spacer works as well as a nebuliser if correctly used
Counsel caregiver to reduce exposure to smoke and strong-smelling odors, including tobacco smoke and biofuels (charcoal, kerosene, waste products)
Refer to assess and treat for potential TB. This will include TB testing and chest x-ray
Give oral AMOXICILLIN 250 mg (1 tablet or 5 ml of 250mg/5ml syrup)
Give oral AMOXICILLIN 500 mg (2 tablets or 10ml of 250mg/5ml syrup)
Give oral AMOXICILLIN 750mg (3 tablets or 15 ml of 250mg/5ml syrup)
Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy
Follow up in 3 days, earlier if worsening
No signs of Pneumonia or Wheezing illness
Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy
Follow up in 5 days if not improving, earlier if getting worse
The Normal breathing rate for children between 2 to 12 months is under 50 breaths per minute
The Normal rate for children ages 1–5 years is under 40 breaths per minute
The Normal rate for children below 2 months is under 60 breaths per minute
A high-pitched whistling sound associated with labored breathing
The lower ribs on both sides of the chest are pulled in when the child breathes in, even when the child is not crying.
Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy
No clear recommendation for inhaled bronchodilators at this time
Counsel caregiver to monitor the child’s breathing and feeding closely
Follow up in 2 days, earlier if getting worse
Give inhaled salbutamol , 4–6 puffs every 4–6 hours for 5 days.
Inhaled salbutamol is preferred to oral salbutamol
Use with spacer [INSERT link to spacer making/teaching]
Follow up in 3 days, earlier if worsening
Consider referral for asthma assessment and management
Trial salbutamol inhaler 2–4 puffs every 4–6 hours for 3 days
In the clinic: Give 4–6 puffs SALBUTAMOL via metered dose inhaler OR 2.5–5mg via nebulized solution. Repeat up to 3 times every 15 minutes
Send the child home with inhaled SALBUTAMOL by metered dose inhaler , 2–4 puffs every 4–6 hours for 5 days, then as needed.
Inhaled salbutamol is preferred to oral salbutamol

A spacer is a way of delivering the bronchodilator drugs effectively into the lungs. No child under 5 years should be given an inhaler without a spacer. A spacer works as well as a nebuliser if correctly used.
Follow up in 3 days, earlier if getting worse
Give the child Ready-to-Use Therapeutic Food (RUTF)
If unable to finish RUTF or breastfeeding problems, give the first dose of the appropriate antibiotic, and refer URGENTLY to the hospital
If able to finish RUTF, Give oral antibiotics for 5 days
Give ready-to-use therapeutic food for a child aged 6 months or more
Counsel the mother on how to feed the child
Assess the child\'s feeding and counsel the mother on the feeding recommendations
If feeding problem, follow up in 7 days. Otherwise, follow-up in 30 days
Give first dose of artesunate or quinine for severe malaria
For the ARTESUNATE suppository: Dosage form: 50mg pediatric or 200mg adult, Give 50mg (1 pediatric suppository).
For the ARTESUNATE suppository: Dosage form: 50mg pediatric or 200mg adult, Give 100mg (2 pediatric suppositories).
For the ARTESUNATE suppository: Dosage form: 50mg pediatric or 200mg adult, Give 150mg (3 pediatric suppositories) OR 200mg (1 adult suppository).
For Intramuscular ARTESUNATE: Dosage form: 60mg vial (20mg/ml), Give 10mg (0.5 ml).
For Intramuscular ARTESUNATE: Dosage form: 60mg vial (20mg/ml), Give 20mg (1ml).
For Intramuscular ARTESUNATE: Dosage form: 60mg vial (20mg/ml), Give 30mg (1.5ml).
For Intramuscular ARTESUNATE: Dosage form: 60mg vial (20mg/ml), Give 40mg (2ml).
For Intramuscular QUININE: Dosage forms: 150mg/ml OR 300mg/ml, Give 0.4ml of 150mg/ml dose form OR 0.2ml of 300mg/ml dose form
For Intramuscular QUININE: Dosage forms: 150mg/ml OR 300mg/ml, Give 0.6ml of 150mg/ml dose form OR 0.3ml of 300mg/ml dose form
For Intramuscular QUININE: Dosage forms: 150mg/ml OR 300mg/ml, Give 0.8ml of 150mg/ml dose form OR 0.4ml of 300mg/ml dose form
For Intramuscular QUININE: Dosage forms: 150mg/ml OR 300mg/ml, Give 1ml of 150mg/ml dose form OR 0.5ml of 300mg/ml dose form
For Intramuscular QUININE: Dosage forms: 150mg/ml OR 300mg/ml, Give 1.2ml of 150mg/ml dose form OR 0.6ml of 300mg/ml dose form
Consider testing for malaria if risk high and no other cause of fever identified
Give PARACETAMOL (Dose forms: 100mg pediatric tablet or 500mg adult tablet) 100mg (1 pediatric tablet) or 125mg (¼ of adult tablet) every 6 hours to relieve high fever
Give PARACETAMOL (Dose forms: 100mg pediatric tablet or 500mg adult tablet) 250mg (1.5 pediatric tablet or ½ adult tablet) every 6 hours to relieve high fever
Encourage the child to take oral liquids
Monitor for signs of dehydration and new or worsening symptoms
Follow up in 5–7 days if no improvement, earlier of worsening symptoms
Remind family to continue with HIV care
Give first dose of oral AMOXICILLIN 250 mg (1 tablet or 5 ml of 250mg/5ml syrup)
Give first dose of oral AMOXICILLIN 500 mg (2 tablets or 10ml of 250mg/5ml syrup)
Give first dose of oral AMOXICILLIN 750mg (3 tablets or 15 ml of 250mg/5ml syrup)
Ensure the child is taking COTRIMAZOLE prophylaxis and antiretroviral therapy
Give COTRIMAZOLE 20/100 mg (2.5 ml syrup or ONE 20/100mg pediatric tab) once daily
Give COTRIMAZOLE 40/200mg (5 ml syrup, TWO 20/100mg pediatric tabs, or ONE HALF 80/400mg adult tab) once daily
Give 2 additional treatments of salbutamol 4–10 puffs each treatment
consider referral for worsening clinical signs and symptoms
An inhaled medication that relaxes constricted air passages to make breathing easier

A spacer is a way of delivering the bronchodilator drugs effectively into the lungs. No child under 5 years should be given an inhaler without a spacer. A spacer works as well as a nebuliser if correctly used.
Spacers can be made in the following way
ONE: Use a 500ml drink bottle or similar
Cut a hole in the bottle base in the same shape as the mouthpiece of the inhaler.
This can be done using a sharp knife.
Cut the bottle between the upper quarter and the lower ¾ and disregard the upper quarter of the bottle.
Cut a small V in the border of the large open part of the bottle to fit to the child\'s nose and be used as a mask.
Flame the edge of the cut bottle with a candle or a lighter to soften it.
In a small baby, a mask can be made by making a similar hole in a plastic (not polystyrene) cup. Alternatively commercial spacers can be used if available.
TWO: To use an inhaler with a spacer
Remove the inhaler cap. Shake the inhaler well.
Insert mouthpiece of the inhaler through the hole in the bottle or plastic cup.

The child should put the opening of the bottle into his mouth and breath in and out through the mouth. A carer then presses down the inhaler and sprays into the bottle while the child continues to breath normally.
Wait for three to four breaths and repeat.
For younger children, place the cup over the child\'s mouth and use as a spacer in the same way.
If a spacer is being used for the first time, it should be primed by 4–5 extra puffs from the inhaler.
If a spacer is being used for the first time, it should be primed by 4–5 extra puffs from the inhaler before giving it to the child.
The lower ribs on both sides of the chest are pulled in when the child breathes in, even when the child is not crying.
Select Mild if the ribs and area below the chest are retracting moderately.
Select Moderate if the above symptoms are present as well as flared nostrils or indrawing below the sternum (upper chest).
Select Severe if there are large retractions in the upper and lower chest areas as well as nostril flaring or grunting noises.
A device that measures the oxygen saturation of blood in a patient.

A device that measures the oxygen saturation of blood in a patient. This clip device may be used on an earlobe, across the bridge of the nose, in the mouth, on a toe, or on a fingertip. Normal levels are above 90 percent.
A spacer is a device that can improve the effectiveness of inhalers by allowing more of the steroids to be inhaled deeply into the lungs.

A spacer is a device that can improve the effectiveness of inhalers by allowing more of the steroids to be inhaled deeply into the lungs. If no spacers are available, they can be improvised using an empty plastic water bottle
Find an empty plastic water bottle and remove the cap.
Cut a hole into the bottom of the bottle in the same shape as the mouth of the inhaler.
Cut the bottle between the upper quarter and lower ¾ and throw away the upper part.
Soften the cut edge of the bottle with a lighter or candle flame.
Insert the inhaler into the bottom opening as shown in the image.
A mask can be made by following the above steps with a plastic cup.
A high-pitched whistling sound associated with labored breathing
Listen to breathing with a stethoscope
Select Mild if the child wheezes somewhat when breathing out
Select Moderate if the child wheezes loudly when breathing out
Select Severe if the child is wheezing loudly breathing in and out and/or the breaths are very soft.
An inhaled medication that relaxes constricted air passages to make breathing easier
If the spacer has never been used, prepare it with 4 puffs from the inhaler.
Put mask over nose and mouth with a good seal.
Breathe normally for 3 to 6 breaths to empty spacer. Slow your breathing if there is a whistle sound.
Remove mask from child’s face and wait 10 seconds
Shake inhaler then start with step 4 before each additional puff.
Wipe skin around child’s mouth with a wet cloth when done.
Reassess child in AT LEAST 10 minutes
Seizures, involuntary shaking movements of the body often caused by serious infections or high fever

A sudden, violent, irregular movement of a limb or of the body, caused by involuntary contraction of muscles and associated especially with brain disorders such as epilepsy, the presence of certain toxins or other agents in the blood, or fever in children.
A medicine used to stop convulsions

Diazepam typically produces a calming effect. It is commonly used to treat a range of conditions including anxiety, alcohol withdrawal syndrome, muscle spasms, seizures, trouble sleeping, and restless legs syndrome. When given into a vein, effects begin in one to five minutes and last up to an hour. By mouth, effects may take 40 minutes to begin.
Lung inflammation caused by bacterial or viral infection

Pneumonia is an inflammatory condition of the lung affecting primarily the small air sacs known as alveoli. Symptoms can include productive or dry cough, chest pain, fever, and trouble breathing. Severity is variable.
A condition in which a person does not respond to questions, commands or painful stimuli
If a person or their body is unresponsive, they do not react physically in a normal way, or do not make any movements.
A noise on breathing in due to obstruction of the upper airway
Stridor is a loud whistling sound made when taking in a breath. It is a sign of upper airway blockage and must be treated right away to prevent the airway from completely closing.
